episode.title: Lo-Ji Sales, Inc. v. New York

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in 78-511, Lo-Ji Sales, Inc. against New York.
Counsel, I suggest you can take your seat until the crowd clears.
Mr. Berkman, I think you may proceed now whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
There are a multitude of reasons why the search and seizures in this case are constitutionally tainted.
Any one of them ought to be sufficient to require the reversal of the conviction below.

First of all, the warrant under which the search was conducted was invalid both because it was issued without probable cause and because it failed to identify with particularity the items which were to be seized.
Second of all, the search was an exploratory, limitless, general search.
Third, the magistrate failed to focus searchingly on the obscenity of the seized items before seizure.
And fourth, because the seizure was so general so pervasive, so massive, it affected a restraint which required an adversary hearing on the question of obscenity in advance of seizure.

We contend that the presence of the magistrate on the premises not only failed to cure the constitutional violations but actually intensified them and we urge that the Fourth Amendment protects the petitioner against the general search and mass seizure which took place here.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if you say that the presence of the magistrate on the premises didn't even nil, it didn't cure the problems to which you've alluded but actually intensified them.
How -- how would the state go about handling the service situation?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, the state went about handling it --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How would it I said in the constitutional means?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, it would seem to me that the entry onto the premises assuming no further rights than any customer might have the purchase or the observation of material which would not involve the authorization of an invalid warrant to search and to seize and without the massive seizure that took place here.
It might be an acceptable way of dealing with the situation.

Heller, I think demonstrates a manner in which this Court has held the seizure of material after a careful focusing upon the entirety of the materials involved was done and handled apparently properly --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you suggesting that the proper procedure was for the officer, for an officer not a judge but an officer to go on the premises of the store and buy selective pieces of material, books and films than take them back, show them to the magistrate or the judge as the basis for getting a warrant at a later point?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: As I read your decision in Heller, Your Honor, it seems to me that that might have been appropriate but there are a number of other ways in which a prosecution ---

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, that is if you concede that's an appropriate way under Heller and other cases.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
And it seems to me there are a number of other ways in which a criminal prosecution might originated.
It might be that some citizen might make a purchase which he regards to be inappropriate and seeks a law enforcement.
It seems to me that the state has myriads of ways without violating both the First, Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments in which they might appropriately deal with the question of obscenity.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I'd understood that the magistrate's premise -- that the magistrate's presence here was in order to assure that before seizure some neutral and detached magistrate would have examined the material.
You -- you said that's simply exacerbates the situation.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, there are a couple of things wrong with the position which has been taken by the State of New York.
One is, in our judgment the seizure was accomplished before the magistrate did anything.

The seizure was accomplished when 11 representatives of the law enforcement agencies went upon the premises, some of them in uniform filtered throughout the store, manned themselves in front of the entrance, took the names and otherwise intimidated persons who might have entered the store, kept the place under a virtual siege for approximately six hours, ransacked the entire premises, took out all of the films that were in the premises, took out all of the projectors that were in the premises not only took out certain articles of clothing which apparently had certain sexual connotations but also took the mannequins upon which they were displayed and either those circumstances, it seems to me that the seizure was effected at the time that they encircle and laid siege to that little bookstore.
That was when it occurred, and occurred before the judge even had the opportunity to focus search on anything.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When the magistrate's presence was neither improves nor detracts from your case.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I only say Your Honor, that if that may well be true, but the problem is that when somebody who appears to be a magistrate or judge and someone to whom in ordinary citizen might go for constitutional relief actually appears on the scene as an executing officer and to a warrant which he himself has issued you have problems of perhaps and even more serious kind when he goes beyond the role that the judge assumed in the Heller case by merely going on to the scene viewing the material and not exercising his prerogative as an authority to make such a search.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you have any problem whether it was 11 or 22 or 33 officers entering the premises buying books, films, and then appear all together or one by one leaving the premises and taking them to a magistrate?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Your Honor, I think the facts would depend on each particular circumstance.
I think that a massive number of law enforcement authorities made themselves be an intimidating and controlling factor.
In this situation, --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let me -- what's the impact, let's assume there's that a proprietor is somewhat intimidated, what's that got to do with what they buy and take to the magistrate?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, I think that if they make a purchase and if they act in -- with no greater act then a customer might, then that might be appropriate.

But it seems to me that it is possible under certain facts for a large number of people to actually take over and effectuate the seizure of the entire store by their presence and control and domination of the place before they have an opportunity to take anything back to a magistrate and under those circumstances, you might have a seizure which is premature under the circumstances that you suggest.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: In this connection, it does not count to relate in part at list to the two films that one officer had purchased?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, does that stand up?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it seems to me that the entire search has got to be looked at under circumstances in which the entirety is considered.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Yes, the searched films -- those films were purchased before the search ever took place.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: But Your Honor, there were other copies of the same film which were actually acquired during --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I am speaking about the two that were taken, that were purchased by the officer.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and I'm suggesting that there were additional copies of those very same films seized in the raid which of which we complained.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well, suppose we invalidate that seizure.
Aren't you still stuck with Count II with respect to the two purchased films.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I would urge not Mr. Justice because it seems to me that if you have a massive seizure then there is no deterrent or prophylactic effect at all if you merely invalidate that part of it which is -- which goes beyond the appropriateness.

Because what happens then is that the police officers are unnoticed that if they exceed the bounds of the First and Fourth Amendment and in this instance with respect to the state as applied to through the Fourteenth then all that will happen in the event that it turns out that they have been excessive in their zeal is that that portion of the material which has exceeded will be returned but the original invasion, the original violation of the constitutional provisions will still have not been remedied.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But Mr. Berkman suppose after this case is over, the same two policemen go in and buy two film, could he be prosecuted?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Two -- I'm sorry, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Two policemen go in and buy two more films?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Two more films.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could he be prosecuted?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It would seem to me that if those films are then focused searchingly on by a detached and neutral magistrate, then perhaps that might go --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I said, they give to this any magistrate, I don't have to -- any magistrate.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, then why is the original seizure good?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, it seems to me Your Honor that there has to be an arrangement in which there is a focusing upon the material --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I thought we had it here?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: In --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The two policemen brought in two films --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- and said we want action to magistrate.
And you said that is gone.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or do I misquote you?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor.
If that is subjected to a judicial scrutiny which passes constitutional --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, on the record of this case?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does that count stand?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It seems to me that it cannot, Your Honor.
Because it is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Because of the?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Because it is a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What happen after that?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It is all partial of the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, but now if it's done afterwards, it's alright?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It may be if assuming --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I want another difference between pro and after.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, when you have a mass seizure such as took place here, my understanding of the teaching of the cases here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That cleans the whole slate?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It seems to me that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Does that clean the whole prior slate?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It seems -- yes, sir, I think it does.
I think --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, why didn't it clean the future slate?
Why is that?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, I think that this case has to stand on its own, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But under my brother Marshall's question, --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- had there just been a purchase of two items, it wouldn't have needed to be a magistrate at all.
There could have just been a prosecution based upon those two items and that would have been up to the jury and the instructions of the judge and it would have been all.
There would not have been a search or seizure.
There has been purchase of two items, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: That's quite right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And I don't really -- what was the purpose do you suppose of this warrant which was signed on the morning of June 25, 1976 even providing for the seizure of items 1 and 2 since those two items are already been purchased and we're in the possession of prosecuting authorities?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Your Honor, quite right.
They were -- they were evidence which is already available --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Which were already in their possession, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It was already in the possession of the prosecuting authority.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Of course it was and it seems to me that the only purpose that there could have been for seizing multiple copies of that film and for seizing other things in the store was to actually close the operation, prevent the exhibition and to block distribution of materials without a prior adjudication.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And it doesn't ----

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: In our judgment, it seems to us that the record demonstrates.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's not this case, isn't it?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He was convicted, was he?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No, he pleaded guilty.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he was convicted but that is this case.
What happened -- what happened here Your Honor was that after having --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think the example can see that you have made a very good argument for action for damages.
But I couldn't see necessarily that that was a defense in lawsuit.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, it seems --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, straighten me up.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, it seems to me first of all that in this case, there was a search and seizure which followed the purchase of two films.
Those two films dealt with only one count.

There were three counts upon which a conviction was obtained based upon the refusal of the court below to grant the motion to suppress evidence because over 400 films appear in Count I which involves a material which was taken solely as a result of what we contend was a defective warrant and a massive search and seizure and with respect to the third count, that involves the seizure of all the projectors and a number of other items, none of which were in the possession of the police officers prior to the search.

Now, it seems to me that with respect to the films that were involved in Count II, there were a multitude of films which were involved apart from the two which had originally been seized and as a matter of fact multiple copies of those two had been seized as a result of the certain seizure and so it is our contention that the bulk of, the basis of the prosecutions on all the counts came as a result of what we contend was an illegal search and seizure.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, how did the conviction come about?
Why did it rest on?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: The conviction occurred after the motion to suppress was denied and the parties pleaded guilty.
Under New York procedure, it is possible to seek appellate review of the denial of the motion to suppress even after a plea of guilty.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, then going back to the suggestion or questions of several other of my colleagues, suppose we agreed with you as to Count I and III and disagreed with you as to Count II which, if I had the numbers correctly as the one, Count II rests on two films which is standing alone, you don't question.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Your Honor, Count II --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that so?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: -- Count II rests on those two films plus hundreds of others.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: And so consequently, we are saying that those are among them but it may well be that those that were taken were the ones upon which the conviction was based and so it seems to me that they are inseverable.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, wait a minute now if we -- if they tried this case, there'd be more of a problem but if they're going to a jury verdict based on all the films, the two plus all the hundreds of others, there's a guilty plea with respect to the two plus others under Count II, is there not?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, it is

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And how -- then how can you, how do you justify challenging the two that they were properly in the possession of the police?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Because the count itself for reasons which I do not know and which were based upon determinations of the law enforcement authorities of New York.
They included in one count, not only the two films which were purchased but also hundreds of others.
Now, it may well be that the guilty plea --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where is the count you're talking about?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 2 (a) and 3 (a).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So is it 3 (a)?
Well, how do you know that the two that receives were included in Count II?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, they were identified in the seizure materials.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well,doesn't the guilty plea waive any defect in the information or indictment?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, we're not claiming that there's a defect in the information or indictment.

We are claiming that the materials upon which the information or indictment are bottomed where themselves obtained by illegal search and seizure and under New York procedure, even after a guilty plea, you are permitted to seek appellate review.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you can see that two items were not, I take it.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: The two -- two of the hundreds of items in Count II had been acquired by a purchase of the police officers and had been viewed in advance by the magistrate prior to the seizure involved here, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And he pleaded guilty with respect to those two along with others?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
With the understanding and it was done after the motion to suppress had been denied and under the provisions of Section 710.70 subsection (2) of the New York Criminal Procedure Code.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And in addition to the two individual items that have been purchased, I suppose under the purported authority of the search warrant, several duplicate copies were seized under paragraph 1, 2 of the search warrant, with the --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- with the same items?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The search warrant does by using the plural reels in both cases authorize the seizure of duplicate copies.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Right.
And in fact everything that was on the premises by way of the duplicate of those two films were seize in the course of debate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where -- where do you find that the two copies that were purchased are included in Count II?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, the films were appeared in Count II and the books appeared in --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but tell me how do you know that among the 474 movie reels mentioned in Count II, how do you know that --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I cannot.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- the two that were bought were --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I cannot tell that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose they weren't?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, then --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then you have no problem?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: None at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how do you know they are even in there?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I don't know that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I thought you could do that by process of going over the inventory?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Only by going over the inventory but it is true, Your Honor that in so far as --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But how would you know which is which?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: You can't tell it.
And it seems to me that because of the ambiguity there --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if the officer bought them and they were his.
It's -- it's a strange way then to say that to charge then somebody with possessing.
He -- maybe he did possess them at one time.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
But if he did possess them, he possessed other copies of the same films which were seized during the course of the raid of which we complained.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And we've said before that that's the one appropriate way to go about it to seize a sample of the particular item.
One sample now as to two films it's clear that that was done, is it not?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is not?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I don't think that is clear because what happen is a result of this was that the entire inventory of the store was ransacked on the basis of what we can't contend to have been an excuse employed in order to make it appear as though there was a search under a warrant.
Once you have two films, it seems to me that the necessity of acquiring two more from a law enforcement standpoint is nil.
The only reason for acquiring --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, unless you want to charge him of the crime of possession because if you have him, he no longer possesses them.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes.

On the other hand, it seems to me that there are abundant opportunities to charge a storeowner under these circumstances with either these films of others on the basis of the conditioning of the store and its inventory.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there's nothing wrong with him, nothing wrong with him going back and buying either 10 more books and I suppose that if the search warrant procedures were valid there'll be nothing wrong will properly carried out, there would be nothing wrong with seizing him under a search warrant if the post procedures were proper.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I think that's right.

As a matter of fact, in view of the fact that only three counts were and there would be no limitation upon the law enforcement power of the State of New York in terms of what it was that was doing under these circumstances in controlling the distribution of what it claimed to be obscenity.
Now, we urge further that the Fourth Amendment protects the petitioner against the general search and mass seizure which took place here.

That just because the petitioner opened its store to invite customers into his premises to buy merchandise does not mean as the State of New York now contends that it's entire expectation of privacy is forfeited to the occupation of its premises by the police force.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose this had been done by one officer? Well, without the 10 --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It seems to me that depends upon what it did.
If he came --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Suppose one officer did everything that the 11 officers did?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It would seem to me then that it would still not be sufficient, Your Honor for the reason --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Because the 11 is -- 11 or 1 is not really crucial to the case?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: No, I think that the massive number only has to do with the -- with part of the facts involving the pervasive seizure and control and domination of the entire enterprise.
The fact is that these police officers did not limit themselves to the position of a customer and the premises.

Indeed, if a customer on the premises had come in and ransacked the material and taken the books off the display shelf and put them on the floor and torn out the cellophane covers, and stood in front and stopped customers from coming in and taking their names and addresses and rummaged through business records and had done all the things that these police officers did, these store proprietor in my judgment would have had the right to call these very policemen and eject them and to bring actions against them for trespass.

And so consequently, they do not stand in the shoes of a normal customer and for that reason, it seems to me that a store proprietor does not move his expectation of privacy with respect to the fact that there will not be a police force which will do the things which have been done here.
Now, it seems to me, Your Honor that we must first take a look at the warrant.

The warrant itself demonstrates nothing by way of probable cause with respect to any other item than the two films themselves which were purchased and reviewed by both the judge and the police officer.

There is a list of things to come, predictions of things to come in Section 3 of the warrant which says that there are bunch of other items that are to be seized as well but they were absolutely blank at the time of the search and seizure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, do you think that if a magistrate accompanies an investigator to a store and he examines books on the shelves and looks at them as much as he wants and then goes back to the office and issues of search warrant to seize one copy of each of the following titles as evidence and he says I have searchingly focused on the issue of obscenity and think there's probable cause to believe they're obscene.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: So long as he does not use his judicial authority to effectuate the search during the time that he's examining the material.
If he acts in a way that the judge in Heller versus New York did, then we would have no objection to that.
What -- what occurred here however is that they took possession of the store and seized its entire contents before any of that judicial review occurred, and there's another problem too.
And that is that when a magistrate issues a warrant after himself have participated in the search and seizure.
He becomes a part of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but if he comes to the store and if he does nothing in the store that any other member of the public could not do.
If he does nothing but what member of the public could do if that's all he did, you would have -- that would be different.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: And he has not use the force of judicial office and he has not effectuated the search.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your client told he didn't have to put a quarter in the movie reels, didn't he?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, as a matter of fact, that is what the record does reflect Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
On the other hand, however, at the time that the police officers arrived in force, they came and announce that this individual was under arrest.
They read him his Miranda rights.

They also announced that they were going to search the premises they produced what purported to be a warrant and under those circumstances it seems to me that he was acquiescing to authority and not consenting to anything that would have any constitutional import.

He was not a free agent under any circumstances during the six-hour period when he was on the premises the officer quite candidly admitted that he was not free to leave, he was under arrest and he was in a situation where a number of officers were all over the store and it would seem to me that the interests of safety and concern might have cause him to make such a comment without in any way having him to be voluntary consent.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that wouldn't be -- that wouldn't reach taking the cellophane or the plastic wrappers of it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: There was never any purported consent of any kind to that, they just came in and took the merchandise off the shelves, piled it on the floor, tore of the coverage because there was a cellophane seal on them which prevents anyone from opening the package and looking inside.

And consequently, there was no suggestion that anyone offered an invitation to the officers to open those seals or to look at business records or to do the myriad other things that occurred during the course of this record.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Berkman, for the constitutional purposes of this case and laying aside for the moment this special consideration given to books as we've indicated in our opinions, is this case any different from what it would be if a warrant had been issued for to pick up two sample cans of spinach on the ground they have information or reason to believe that they might be contaminated and the two cans of spinach were seized and then all the things that happened here with reference to the other merchandise occurred.
All of the canned goods in the grocery store and all the red and everything else was taken.
Is it fundamentally any different?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, it would seem to me it's fundamentally different because of the First Amendment --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I said except for that, they never signed.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: And also, it is unclear when a criminal prosecution occurs as to whether or not the cans of spinach are even involved.
I would think that that would be a substantial difference.

I think that if there's probable cause to seize the spinach in a numbers that you suggest, that in itself suggest no Fourth Amendment problems and so long as the materials are particularly described, I don't see that that raises any --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But the Food and Drug Administration does make seizures at times, do they not?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I understand that.
I understand that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But I take it from your point of view they can't seize all the spinach in the store until they determine on the basis of sampling that some of it is contaminated.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, except for the considerations are probable cause in particularity, Your Honor, which are requirements with respect to all Fourth Amendment seizures.
It would seem to me that you have special prior restraint problems when you have First Amendment material which doesn't apply to spinach.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But so far the Fourth Amendment concerned, there is no difference, is it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: So long as the particularity and specificity and probable cause requirements have been met, it would seem to me.
And then of course, I think it would depend upon whether or not a warrant were required and all of those considerations, I think that would --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: One of the reasons -- isn't the principle is that they have cellophane wrappers or the books to prevent freeloaders from reading them and without buying them.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, there's nothing in the record on that subject but I would suppose that that might be affected.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, are you saying then that a police officer has to buy the book before he can inspect it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: I think that either he has to acquire in some lawful way or it may well be that a customer or somebody else has acquired certain material.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But you say a police officer can inspect the book -- cannot inspect the book on the premises by tearing the cellophane coverall.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: It seems to me that he's limited to performing in the way that a customer will be permitted to conform if he exceeds that then he's acting as a policeman and not as a customer and exceeds any such responsibility, and I think that becomes a seizure.
Now, I think --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The mere tearing of the wrapper becomes a seizure?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Yes, I think that as this Court has indicated in Terry and recently in Delaware against Prouse, very little is required in order to effectuate a seizure either of a person or --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In fact, it could be like breaking the can of spinach open with a can opener and --

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: A can of spinach could be, Your Honor or opening the trunk of Mr. Chadwick in the Chadwick case.
You know, any of those items seems to me effectuates a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The real difference between a customer and a policeman is the customized money.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Isn't the real difference?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, I apparently --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The customer buys something and pays for it?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
But it acquires in a lawful manner and that of course is attached to him which I think is constitutional implication.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you said it is law but it is not but it is warning.
The policeman implied (Inaudible) while in there place, didn't he?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, except for the two books that they originally purchased.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, I mean when the others went in with the magistrate.

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: That's right, they didn't know --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Nobody then -- isn't that the real difference?

turn.speaker: bernard_a_berkman
turn.label: Mr. Bernard A. Berkman
turn.text: Well, I think that the difference is because of legal acquisition and acquisition by something other than the authority of the state which makes the constitutional difference.

The attempt by the state to deal with the warrant by after the fact adding 14 pages to a two-page warrant demonstrates the importance of their concern at the warrant be the basis upon which state attempted to search.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Berkman.
Mr. Parker.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
My name is Richard Parker, I'm an Assistant District Attorney from Goshen, New York, that's a small upstate county.

The legislature of the State of New York has declared an uncertain terms how a public policy to be the protection of moral decency and in furtherance oft this public policy it has authorized the various units of the state to prosecute criminal possession of promoting obscene material.

In order to effectuate this police policy against the commercial establishment which has a large number of obscene items and obscene material, we have tried after studying this Court's decisions to come up with the procedure which on one hand will protect First Amendment rights and on the other hand gives us an opportunity to effectuate this legislative policy.
In effect we try to do is following a fair middle ground.
What we did in this case was have a police officer go to the store and look around the store.

He then bought a small sample of two items and to clarify for the record, Mr. Mandagas, the clerk of the store was charged for possessing with intent promoting these two items on the day that these items were sold.
The officer --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where do you see that?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where do you see that charge in the appendix?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, that's a footnote I believe in my brief.
Mr. Mandagas case is not on appeal.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He subsequently pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct, was given a conditional --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: -- that was given a conditional --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For possessing those two items on the day they were purchased?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, promoting those two items on the day they were purchased.
Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, they aren't included in these 400 and some films?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: They are -- the same films are included but those two items are --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How do you know they are?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: From the inventory.
The inventory and the search warrant tells you at the inventory least all 472 items which the reels and films were list all the magazines and list the names of all the films that were --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you certainly wouldn't list these two items that have been bought on the search warrant or an inventory of things that have been seized in the search warrant cause they weren't seize in the search warrants before.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, but other copies of the -- that were --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but I'm talking about these two copies.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, right.
Were these two copies --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that so -- so that those are out?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's all I wanted to know.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, I want to clarify that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the only ones -- so the only ones on which this conviction rest are the ones that receives in the search and seizure under the warrant.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, and if you look at the criminal charges, the basis of these charges are promoting the items on June 20th the date of these seizure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now say, let's assume that when these two films were bought and they were brought back to the judge, suppose the judge had look at and them and said I have now focused on the nature of these articles.
I've read them from cover to cover.
There's probable cause to think that they are obscene.
I hereby authorize you to go back to the store and seize all other copies of these two books.
Do you -- tell me what case in this Court would warrant that.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I don't believe any case in this case Court would warrant that alone.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As a matter of fact, the client -- the cases that would say that would be forbidden?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, but I think there's an important distinction in this case and that was that when we went in to this bookstore and before there was any seizure, we entered the store was open to the public.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: When we went in there, the clerk was given the warrant and was told that he had the right to an immediate adversary hearing as soon as he would be ready or the owner of those materials --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but before the hearing -- whenever the hearing was either that it was tomorrow or this afternoon, you took all copies out of circulation?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Temporarily, we did, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, tell me some case that warrants that --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I believe under Kingsley Books, we can do that.
The Kingsley Books, there was a case where more than one copy of the book was taken.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought there had to be an adversary hearing before you completely remove from circulation all copies of materials like this.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, I don't believe, I believe Kingsley Books are the Court held that you could temporarily take those items and then hold an adversary hearing afterwards.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, the Kingsley Books was interim in injunction, it wasn't seizure?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because what we're talking about is Marcus and Quantity of Books.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I believe this is different from Marcus and Quantity of Books.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Different from what my brother White has just been suggesting?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How is it different?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: It's different because the items were taken as evidence, a judge had viewed the items and made a probable course determination plus it's different because after they were taken --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, but Marcus and Quantity of Books said you can't seize the whole group without having the adversary proceeding first.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, I believe they said you cannot seize them for destruction purposes.

We were seizing them for evidence purposes to bring a criminal prosecution and we were going to bring that as soon as we possibly could and I should add that at no time did the petitioner in this case ever asked for any hearing as to the obscenities.
As a matter of fact, he pleaded guilty as to the obscenity of all the items.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, after you -- after you denied this motion to suppress you took advantage of your New York statute which spend them do that.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's right but under our New York statute, he could have a trial on the issue of obscenity and if he --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but New York statute permitted them to do just exactly what he did.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's right but it certainly did in anyway inhibit from also having a trial as if he thought the items were not obscene.
He could have had that trial also.

The reason I feel that this procedure is fair and proper is because we have the safeguards of having a prior judicial officer look at the interior before it seize -- the officer had an -- the judicial officer first had --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the judicial officer at the -- spent six hours in there, was he still a judicial officer?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I believe he was --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or was he a bias person?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I think that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That to be in there looking at the material for six hours, wouldn't he be influenced one way of the other?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Oh, I believe the material may influence --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Wouldn't he be influenced one or another?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I think that material may influence but I don't think it changed his being bias.
I think the record shows that all times he did what he thought should be done.
He was leading the party.
In other words, he made the determinations what should be taken and what should not be taken.
He made the determination whether or not an item should be taken.
Even towards the end, I think it's clear from the record.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If you had a hearing who decide over the hearing?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: There would have -- well at the hearing, there would have been a different judicial officer presiding this.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Oh, he authorized it after the fact, that's the problem.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: After -- well, I don't believe him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They would break the cellophane and bring the book to him and he'd say okay, I had that today, yes, that's okay.
Seize that.
But they'd already seized it.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, I disagree that they had already seized anything.
As a matter of fact, I feel if the judge had gone through this entire store and determine that everything --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, wasn't it, wasn't it testimony that he wasn't free to leave, he was under arrest?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The testimony was that he was told that there was award for his arrest.
He was free to move freely throughout the store.
He was brought a meal.
He moved freely throughout --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what do you mean when you say you moved freely throughout the store?
Doesn't that mean, you're not free to move outside?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, he would not have been free to move outside.
And our --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So there was a seizure when they walked in there, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: There was a seizure of his person but not a seizure of the material.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what do you need 11 for?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, the reason --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was he a rough man or something?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, I think the reason that you had all these people here was to try to do the search.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: These weren't people.
These were police.
They are different from people.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Oh, I have considered policeman a person, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They are different from the average person.
One is they have a gun.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, they do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's different from -- do you have a gun?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, that's different, isn't it?
Well, when you send 11 police in there, you say isn't that seizure?
I wonder what is it, a visit?
A friendly visit?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I think the reason you have the number of these people is so you can expedite the procedure as quickly as possible.
We have people there.
You have one person who was there who was recording what the judge was doing.
There were other people there who were gathering the items that the judge had told them to seize.
There were other people there who would put things in order so the judge can review as quickly as possible.
There were other people who were at the front of the store to find out --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well the things that they put together for the judge were they seized?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, they weren't, I don't believe.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What were they, detained?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He makes -- well, they were in the store, they were left in the store, they were in a pile and they would --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They put it -- could the owner take them away from it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I suppose he could of if he wanted to but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It would be big enough?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It was big enough?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I don't think they would afford them.
There was no -- no indication of that.
But --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But my problem is that a warrant by definition is a prior authorization.
It's a prior authorization issued upon probable cause.
Particularly, describing the place to be search and the thing, there are things to be seized and there was not a prior authorization here.
Here he says the judge in the store there first ordered the police to rip off the sealed plastic which completely enclosed each of the magazines and many of the books in the store.
Then he looks through him.
But that's not a prior authorization.
There was a seizure before the authority to do it.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, I think if you look at it --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the problem because a warrant by definition is a prior authorization.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The State of New York has upheld this which is in effect an oral warrant and they have upheld under this circumstances where you're dealing with books and films and magazines where you have to have a judge go in and look at it prior.
They have said and they have --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's the reason this case is here because the New York courts upheld it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, but they have --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Parker, you -- when you're making a search incident to arrest and you find a gun on a man, you don't have to pay the man the price of the gun, don't you?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, you don't, Your Honor.
But the point I'd like to make there is that what we've -- the function of a warrant, the purpose of the warrant as you've stated Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is prior authorization.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: If one foot have prior authorization of probable cause and to the limit the police discretion by particularly describing what they should take.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: This judge, looked at the material --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: After it had been seized?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, I submit it wasn't after it had been seized.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Because I see -- in other words, I submit that there was no seizure of material that was left in the store.
There were many items that he looked at determined were not obscene and he left them in the store.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, how about looking in -- how about taking the cellophane off of the package?
Isn't that a search?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: In a way it's a search but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in a way, you certainly just can't pat it down like you can if you -- and tell if it's obscene.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's -- well, but you see these magazines --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You know, sometimes you can pat people down and discover and see if the -- but you can't search them.
Here they took cellophane off the packages and actually looks the books.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, but they were taking a cellophane off the books which had obscene photographs at the front of the books which is almost identical to seeing a bold outside someone in patting him down that.
I believe that the judge given the nature of this market would have had the right to after seeing an obscene photograph asked the police --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll resume there at 1 o'clock, Mr. Parker.
Counsel, you may resume.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
I respectfully submit to the Court that the seizure of more than one copy does not invalidate the entire search.
It must be remembered that under New York law, a person is prosecuted not for merely possessing the item but for promoting the item.
Now, obviously this is a commercial.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's an understatement seizing more than one, isn't it?
You seize them all.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, we did not seize everything.
We left many magazines but --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know but did you seize all the copies in any magazine?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, any -- yes, anytime that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So that was rather an understatement?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Anytime the judge after viewing the item felt that there was probable cause to believe --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you seize all of the item?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He seize every copy in that store but there was never any claim made that this person did not have access to other items or could not bring him in the next day.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But he could not sell those particular items?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He could not sell those items.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Didn't that have some resemblance to prior restraint?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Oh, obviously --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They took all the books of a particular category.
They couldn't sell them.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He could not sell them.
That doesn't mean they were not available to the public in the area.
There were other stores --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But I'm talking about restraint on him.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, is it -- yes, there was but that --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you know?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: -- res -- right, but that restraint I submit was a temporary restraint because he had the right to a full hearing and also that restraint was for valid evidentiary purpose to show that he was promoting the item.

Under our law, there is a presumption that if you possess six or more of the same items and it's presumptive evidence that you posses with intent to promote and what we had to show aside from that fact that the items were themselves obscene that this person was promoting obscenity on the day in question.
So there was a valid evidentiary reason to seize them.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If you didn't have to seize them all to show that, they're actually been testimony.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, obviously there could be testimony but the best evidence would be shown in the jury the fact that you have this many items.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or if you want to be a little more sure, maybe it takes six plus, one plus six?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, if you, as you can see for more brief, very few, I think only two or three case and they seized more than six.
Most of the items of the vast majority only one item was seized and then there are small time you took two of the items.
Most of them are one or two items were seized.
Very few was there more than six being seized of more than five being seized.
Now, the other method, another point should be made is that you have three separate pleas of guilty and under the third count for the films in the pictures.
There were no duplicate seizures there.
That count was entitled to separate that was the first part of the search and there were no duplicates.
The only thing that was seized was that one copy of the film that was being displayed to the public.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could that be that there were no duplicate?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could it be that there weren't any duplicates?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: There weren't duplicates.
There was one copy that was there and that was what it was seized.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So they didn't more able to seize, it wouldn't matter?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Probably.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the projectors were seized?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, the projectors were seized.
Again, to show promotion.

Now, the other method that's been suggested is to go in and to buy the item but unfortunately in a small upstate county like we have, we don't have the funds to go and then buy all the obscene items that are being displayed and exploited to the public because the affidavit of petitioner in support of his allegations for a search warrant.
He -- he said that we took $15,000.00 worth of material, that's what he says his quest was.
I've never told that it up.
But assuming his figure is correct our entire investigatory budget for the whole county to fight all crime in our county is only $20,000.00.
We wouldn't have enough funds, public funds to go and expend to buy all the obscene material that's being promoted.
So the only -- I mean we cannot go in there and buy one or two copies or buy one copy of each item that is just not enough money in our budget to do it.
This is really the only effect of way we have to enforce our legislative policy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What was the -- there was a plea of guilty?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What -- there never was a sentence.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, the sentence was a fine of $1,000.00 on each count.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On each separate case?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Separate count?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Each separate count had a fine of $1,000.00 and that fine has been paid.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And how many counts were there?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Three.
Three separate counts.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So now you have $22,000.00?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: What?
No, we don't get that fine money.
That goes to the state.
I submit that the procedure we employed here is a limited procedure which protects First Amendment Rights.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Protects them?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.
And first of all, the entry into the store under this procedure is limited to stores when they're open to the public.
It's the items that are being viewed are limited to the judge viewing items that are being openly displayed to the public.
You have a judge or a judicial officer who was viewing the item before anything has taken from the store --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: After he rips it open?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: After -- yes, after it's been ripped open.
But you have a cover on this which gives him I submit probable cause to make further inquiry to see if the item is obscene especially after a police officer has gone in has found out that this --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Eleven police officers?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, initially one police officer goes in, he brought a small sample --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He needed the support of 10 others?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, to make the search.
He needed that support in order to make it as quick as possible so that it would be the least amount of restraint as possible.
Well, restraint in the sense it takes time if you have one judge.
If the judge goes in by himself, it's going to take a much longer to go everything to look at everything and to gather the staff and take it out of the store.
So then petitioner would claim that it was a longer restraint.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But it took him six hours, didn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: It did take him six hours cause he had a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I guess if it was only one, it would be a couple of days, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I believe it would take much longer, I can't tell you how long it would take.
But I --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Off -- no, I get a new member of the public would have the privilege of going in and looking at all these movies and these machines.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Certainly, they have the privilege of going and looking at the movies and the machine.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's for a quarter?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.
And the judge in this case and the record clearly indicates that the judge offered to put a quarter in every machine and the clerk of the store said it won't be necessary.
I can turn them all on so it will be quicker.
And he voluntarily turned them on.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, you say that wasn't the search?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I'm saying that the viewing --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That wasn't the search because any member of the public could have done it with the court.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: What I'm saying is that the viewing of the material which is openly displayed to the public, there is no reasonable expectation of this petitioner that the public will not see this material.
I'm saying that that viewing is not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All there is on -- there is in the cellophane package with it unless the public buys it and pays the money?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

But in other words, the items are not being hidden from the public, it's not -- when you think of the word search, you think of looking for substance being hidden, this is not material that's being hidden.
This is material that's being displayed openly to the public in areas of the store open to the public.

At no time that any member of law enforcement where this judge ever go into a storeroom or to see what was not being displayed to the public, it was limited to the public areas that items that were openly displayed to the public.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What happened to business records?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The business records were seized to show --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But why they didn't

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: -- to promotion --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I mean they were not in the public area, were they?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: They were behind the front desk, I believe.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, I mean you said everything was out in the public area but --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Everything that he was charged with possessing under this statute under this information was limited to public areas.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And -- but they did go into the private area?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: They went behind the counter, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But what right did they have behind the camera?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Cause that's where the clerk of the store had stationed himself.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do I understand that the man you said the only thing they did and the only place they went was to ride a public land?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, you admit they did go to some place that the public didn't go.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The clerk was there --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The clerk --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
