turn.text: They went behind to arrest the clerk.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And the public didn't go behind?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, I don't believe the public would go behind it.
But they did go behind it to arrest him, the clerk.

Now, I would say that at the time of entry based upon the fact that the officer had learned from the clerk that the store was selling this sex-type material on June 20th when he bought two items and the judge had in fact reviewed two of those items in their entirety that the judge certainly had probable cause to believe they're going to be other items in the store of a commercial being exploit on a commercial nature which was sexually obscene material.
And I think this may give him on other basis.
On that claim, that was the basis he used but I am claiming that he certainly have reason to look at other items in the store.

Had a reason to believe that in this type of market which is exclusively selling sexually explicit material that the he certainly had a right to look at whatever was being displayed to the public to make an initial screening so that he could determine for himself whether or not there was probable cause to seize it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, let me get it clear.
Do you say that all of the movies -- movie reels in Count II are different?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Not all are different.
There some duplicates.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, anyone that he looked at that he thought was obscene he seized all copies of that film?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay counsel.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, he did.

But the issue of the way he focused on the material which has been raised by counsel has to be under -- it must be emphasized that this focusing the market where this was done that the judge had first seen two short films in their entirety and then gone into the booths and seen parts.
And I say its substantial part of many of each of these films and continuously would see films which were just depicting one sex act after another.

I submit that in this type of market, a judge could do enough of initial search without having to see the entire item to know that there's probable cause to believe it's obscene and to bring it into court so there can be a criminal prosecution --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Are you -- are there any cases, I think there is a case that involves projector -- seizing projectors but do you know of any case that involves seizure of all projectors so that the person in the business of showing movies has to order a new projector in order to show anything?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
I'm not aware of anything.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because even -- I take it you left him some films didn't you?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I don't believe he was left any films.
I believe all the films were taken out of the store.
They were books and magazines were left in the store.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, but if he wanted to show some films that weren't obscene, he wouldn't still wouldn't have any projector, would he?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: He would not have, no.
But I think that throughout the procedure that we were not trying to suppress the material or try to close the store, what we try to do from the beginning was find a --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He point down the moving picture part of the store for sure.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: We did do it temporarily but what -- the point was from the beginning, we try to do this in such a way that we could effectively carry out the legislative mandate to protect more of decency but we did it in such a way that this individual was first of all he was given written notification of his right to an immediate hearing before any seizure at all.
That was in the warrant.
He was --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What did you have after you seized 400 films that you wouldn't have had if you'd only seize 10?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, what you would it -- the diff --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you'd seize 10 and one projector and then he went to trial on that. What would you have had --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: You would not have a judicial ruling on whether or not the other 390 or whether it is the other 208 different films whether or not those were obscene.
Each film is a different film.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You ran the risk of those particular 10 would be found to be not obscene I suppose.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: If they're found not obscene then we leave him and he can display them openly and promote them to the public if there's a ruling that they're not obscene.

We have no -- we don't mind that but we're trying to do in effect is find an effective way to protect more of decency given the fact they have a large commercial store which is selling a vast number of obscene items.

We want to bring all these items into court as quickly as we can, as efficiently as we can so we can get a full prompt judicial review as to each of these items to determine that they are in fact obscene.
And before we do that, we ask the judge to give as initial determination that they were in fact obscene.
That there was probable cause to believe they were obscene and then we gave them the right to litigate it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On this thesis, you didn't need more than one copy of each --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Not, but you did need it because they are brought in for criminal purposes and the criminal law is not mere possession.
It's promoting and we have to also show promoting.
Unless, there's going to be stipulation to promote it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you can have evidence to how many they were.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You don't always just believe witnesses there in Goshen, do you?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: No, they don't but the best evidence is always having the actual material there.
And I would submit that since they had the right to have it, to get the hearing immediately as soon as they were ready that a temporary restraint of this sort would not invalidate the entire search.

Perhaps the Court would order that the other materials should have been returned but if the violation of the law in this case is that they took too many copies under the First Amendment then I think the appropriate remedy would not be exclusion under the Fourth Amendment of the entire search.
But would be to order the court, order the police to return the extra copies and then let the conviction stand.

Now, I think that if you look -- that looking at the entire procedure that we follow in order to try to find a fair, middle ground to bring all these items into Court that this is the only procedure, fair procedure that you can use.
There's no other procedure that would effectively work to bring this vast number of items into court.

You can't subpoena the items because if you try to subpoena, you should come to the exact same situation that if you wait for the issue to be joined, you ran the risk that the items are going to disappear, either claim that they been sold in due course or in this case, we deal with a corporation that's an out-of-state corporation that runs a store if we subpoena.
Make the subpoena just take against that corporation as in fact as happens in this case, he changes corporate identity and there's further delay so we lose the items.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose you'd seize a copy of a book of which there were 100 copies in the store and you had a trial two days later, adversary trial that was determined to be obscene.
You could go back and get all the rest of them?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's correct, if they're still there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what would be the -- if they were still there.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That is the problem, if they are still there.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: What's the harm if they're not still there?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, the harm if they're not still there is that we've gone as we allowed the person --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Verdict convicted him now this two-day trial?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Okay.
Okay, you allow him in the interim to continue to sell --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Immaterial this anymore.
Why hypothesis they gone out of state.
Now how is your state hurt by that?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: What?
No, they haven't gone that.
They don't go -- they don't have to go out of state.
The corporation only have to do is change the corporate name.
They went to build it.
An out-of-state corporation comes in and says, we're running --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: By changing the name, do they move the books?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, now you have a new corporation that you have to go after.
You have to start all over again which means that is going to be judicial to language which means that material can be sold in the interim.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you'd be inconvenienced?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I think that I think that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you would be inconvenienced?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Yes, I think --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It means for prosecution?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: It would be much difficult certainly.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, you'd be inconvenienced.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: There's certainly be difficulties involved in that -- but I think --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And consider civil remedies against this people or you get an injunction against operating?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: The getting an injunction would have been -- is completely analogous in order to insure that the evidence was there, you have to get a temporary restraining order to get the restraining order or to keep them there you would have to, I would submit bring the judge to the store to at least make an initial determination that there's reason to get the restraintor recieve a restraint --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Why don't you just subpoena the material if he's filed a civil suit?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Because if you subpoena the material well, if you subpoena the material, you have judicial delay, you have the problem that if you subpoena it, you have to have a reason to subpoena it so you have to have initial determination --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Or you when you -- why do you need a reason to subpoena if you got a couple of copies that are obscene?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: But then you are going to have to subpoena the other copies which are in the store and you haven't review them initially yet unless you get a judge to go in and initially review them so you have probable cause --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: You don't have discovery in New York?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Not, no, we could not.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: If you don't have discovery in New York?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: We couldn't discover it like that.
We would have to have a judge initially view it, get a temporary restraining order to maintain the status quo and enjoin issue and that's really what we did here.
We took it we temporarily have it in our possession until the issue was joined.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In the State of New York, is there any other procedure that allows the magistrate to do what was done here?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor, I don't follow when you say --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if you got a bucket shop running, can the magistrate go into the bucket shop and open up all the books and look at them?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I believe he have a booking shop the magistrate will not have to because the police officer could do that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I didn't say booking shop, I said bucket shop.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Bucket?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, where you sell stocks and bonds over the telephone.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could he go in there.
Is there any other place that you can go in like this other than a pornographic store?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I would think the judge would have --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Give me one then.
Let me see which one has --

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: There's noting written by statute but I think the judge --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: It's not written in statute.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: For example you wouldn't go in your racetrack in Goshen and do that, would you?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: To go in there?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In Goshen, you wouldn't in that racetrack and go in there and seize all that books, would you.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: If that -- if what I'm doing if there was probable cause to believe --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That there were selling dirty books?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Or if there was --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: One other thing?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Well, let's assume that the racetrack was illegally gambling, taking that's illegally --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Name me an instance where it happened?

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I cannot name you another instance, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Any place in New York.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I cannot name you another state that I'm personally aware of.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Any place else in the United States and then I'm going to the world.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: I cannot name you an instance of that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your time has expired, counsel.

turn.speaker: richard_l_parker
turn.label: Mr. Richard L. Parker
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
